Title.evidence: BASIL-2: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Revascularization Strategies in CLTI

Trial_Design.evidence: BASIL-2 was an open-label, multicentre, phase 3 randomised controlled trial

Participants.evidence: conducted in 41 vascular surgery units across the UK, Sweden, and Denmark

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to either VB-first or BET-first strategies

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the cost-effectiveness and cost-utility of a vein bypass (VB) first versus a best endovascular treatment (BET) first revascularization strategy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was amputation-free survival (AFS) over a 2- to 7-year follow-up period

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: BASIL-2 was an open-label, multicentre, phase 3 randomised controlled trial

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 345 participants were randomised (172 to VB-first, 173 to BET-first) between July 2014 and November 2020

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis

Result_Outcome.evidence: BET-first showing lower costs (–£2,524, 95% CI –£5,845 to £1,132). BET-first was more effective, yielding additional amputation-free life years (AFLYs) (0.429, 95% CI 0.03 to 0.88) and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) (0.016, 95% CI –0.08 to 0.12)

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered with ISRCTN27728689
